awd_titl_txt: Enhanced Marine and Environmental Science Training for Pacific Island Community College Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address a critical need to enhance the technical workforce of Pacific Islanders who are trained to address regional ecosystem stress and degradation. The project plans to strengthen and modernize the marine and environmental science training of Pacific Islanders at five minority-serving community colleges: American Samoa Community College, College of Micronesia – Federated States of Micronesia, College of the Marshall Islands, Northern Marianas College, and Palau Community College. The future of these islands and their populations depends on the technical skills and knowledge of local resource managers, policy makers, businesses and stakeholders. This project will support training of faculty and students to increase the success rate of Pacific Islanders in STEM disciplines, which has traditionally been low. 

This project builds on prior Advanced Technological Education projects that helped to establish the marine and environmental programs at the five minority-serving community colleges of the Pacific Islands. The goal of this project is to develop and increase the participation of Pacific Islanders in STEM technical careers. The project aims to provide: 1) enhanced regionally relevant curricula; 2) professional development for community college faculty and secondary school teachers; and 3) experiential learning for students. The project will incorporate input from local agencies, businesses, and stakeholders that have identified key technological skills needed by community college graduates to fill positions within the government, non-government organizations, and private sector. The formative and summative evaluation will use multiple methodologies sensitive to indigenous cultures. The technical skills and training obtained by students will allow them to serve their home islands in critical areas, including natural resource assessment, management, protection, restoration, and resilience. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation’s economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past four years, the National Science Foundation’s Advanced Technological Education (NSF-ATE) program, titled “Partnership for Advanced Marine and Environmental Science Training for Pacific Islanders," has successfully enhanced scientific and technological skills by expanding opportunities in STEM for faculty members and their students across five community colleges in the Pacific Islands: American Samoa Community College, the College of Micronesia – FSM, the College of the Marshall Islands, Northern Marianas College, and Palau Community College. The program has effectively equipped students with modern science skills and technological competencies that are highly valued by academics, researchers, and businesses in the Pacific Region. Graduates recognize the critical role that science careers play in sustaining their islands’ natural resources and Indigenous ways of life and are enthusiastic about pursuing these career pathways.

Fifty four students graduated from their community colleges. Twenty-two student graduates continued to pursue education at the university level: UH Manoa, UH Hilo, United States Coast Guard Academy, the University of Guam, and the University of the South Pacific. Twenty-one students accepted jobs in STEM. The agencies who hired our students include the following: American Samoa’s Division and Community Based Fisheries Management Program, Conservation Society in Pohnpei, Japan Association of Mineralogical Sciences, Marine and Environmental Research Institute of Pohnpei, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Coral Reef Fellowship, Federated States of Micronesia National Government agency responsible for managing the FSM's fisheries resources, Palau International Coral Reef Center, and Pohnpei State Resource and Development. 

Fifty two students accepted internships during this project. These students have presented their research (internships) to their local communities, at college symposia, and/or national/international scientific conferences, building leadership skills and growing their professional networks. Many of these students have presented multiple times, and for our program, we recorded seventy presentations over four years. Thirteen organizations provided mentors, created projects, and offered resources to support the interns and their research. Our top three organizations that support our students year after year include: Fagatele Bay National Marine Sanctuary (American Samoa), Department of Coastal Resource Management (CNMI), and the Palau International Coral Reef Center (ROP).

Over the past four years, our faculty and staff have actively pursued professional development. They have enrolled in grant writing and ROV building training. Faculty members and the educational specialist have represented this project at fifteen conferences. 

This project attracted seventeen agencies located across the Pacific Islands, with six of them new to supporting our program. The agencies within the Pacific Island region provided research opportunities, skills training, and stakeholder engagement. For example, faculty from the University of Bremen in Germany met with two of our faculty members and five of their students at the International Coral Reef Conference. They explored research opportunities through student exchanges with PCC. Southwest Community College and Palomar Community College collaborated with PCC to host their first drone training camp. Ocean Diagnostics, LLC, from British Columbia, Canada, who had developed two groundbreaking sensors to measure microplastics, provided these sensors, allowing each college involved in this grant to utilize them once received. These partnerships have demonstrated that our colleges can actively engage with industry leaders, who recognize the colleges’ marine and environmental research capabilities and student talent pool. Furthermore, the colleges ensured alignment between the companies' technical needs and the students’ technical skills. These outcomes indicate that the colleges can maintain and grow strong relationships with key decision-makers from their local agencies and broader industries.
